importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, a significant development in the nation's space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The mission is part of Pakistan's recent push to expand its space program, with three satellites launched in 2025, including the hyperspectral H1 satellite.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025.
The H1 satellite is a major milestone in Pakistan’s space program and is expected to enhance national capabilities in agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management.
Hyperspectral technology enables detection of subtle material and chemical changes on the ground, allowing for precise crop quality assessment, water resource tracking, and geohazard identification.
The satellite's data will support climate resilience, improve agricultural productivity, and aid in managing natural resources efficiently.
The launch reflects Pakistan’s growing strategic partnership with China, particularly in peaceful space exploration and development projects like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
Two other satellites—EO-1 and KS-1—are already fully operational in orbit, indicating an expanding space program.
It may take approximately two months to fully calibrate and operate the H1 satellite before it becomes fully functional.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The primary subject of the article, as Pakistan is launching its first hyperspectral satellite, marking a key advancement in its national space program and technological development.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entity responsible for launching and managing the H1 satellite, signaling Pakistan’s institutional commitment to space science and technology.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central technological achievement of the article, enabling advanced Earth observation capabilities for agriculture, environmental monitoring, and disaster response.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A satellite launch site in China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location where Pakistan’s H1 satellite was launched, indicating international collaboration and reliance on Chinese launch infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key partner in Pakistan’s space program, providing launch services and reflecting broader strategic and economic cooperation between the two nations.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development linking China’s Xinjiang province with Pakistan’s Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite’s geohazard detection capabilities are expected to support infrastructure development and safety within CPEC, enhancing project sustainability.

namedEntities.name: EO-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A fully operational satellite launched by Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Highlights Pakistan’s growing space capabilities, as it is one of three satellites launched this year and is already operational in orbit.

namedEntities.name: KS-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A fully operational satellite launched by Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Demonstrates the expansion of Pakistan’s space program, with two other satellites already in operation alongside the new H1 satellite.

namedEntities.name: Ministry of Foreign Affairs – Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entity that officially announced the significance of the launch and emphasized the strategic partnership with China.

namedEntities.name: Dawn newspaper
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of a quote from SUPARCO chairman Muhammad Yousuf Khan, adding credibility and context to the satellite’s potential impact.

namedEntities.name: The News International
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of information about the operational status of EO-1 and KS-1 satellites, supporting the narrative of Pakistan’s space program expansion.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, marking a major milestone in its space program. The satellite, equipped with hyperspectral imaging technology, enables detailed analysis of crop health, water resources, and geohazard risks, supporting national efforts in agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management. This advancement reflects Pakistan’s growing strategic partnership with China, particularly in space technology and infrastructure development like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While H1 is expected to become fully operational after about two months of calibration, two earlier satellites—EO-1 and KS-1—are already in orbit and fully functional, indicating a broader trend of technological growth in Pakistan’s space capabilities.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
